chunks.chunk_text: Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Georgie. And I'm Beth. Georgie, what do apples, carrots and celery have in common with insects like beetles, crickets and grasshoppers? That's a tough one, Beth. I'm going to say I can fit them all in my backpack.

Some examples are foods that crunch. There's something very satisfying about the crunch when you bite into a fresh apple, a stick of celery or even a roasted beetle. Yes, that's right. In some parts of the world, edible insects are crunched too.
Danielle says there's nothing better in the world than the crunch of a fresh apple. She uses the phrase,

pleasures, an experience she finds enjoyable. But why are we so attracted to crunchy food? That's what we'll be investigating in this programme, along with some useful new vocabulary, all of which you can find on our website, bbclearningenglish.com. But first, I have a question for you, Georgie. Like Danielle, many British people enjoy the crunch of an apple. But according to a 2024 YouGov study, which is the most popular type of apple in the UK? Is it

I'm going to say a pink lady because that's my favourite. Ah, and me. OK, we'll find out the answer later in the programme. As well as the satisfying sound of a loud crunch, the texture of crunchy food is important too. It tells our bodies to get ready for the raw and rough fibre needed to develop our chewing muscles and teeth.
Crunchy food keeps us healthy, as Danielle explains to BBC World Service's The Food Chain.

When we put food in our mouths, we need to know it's safe. A loud crunch means this food is fresh and OK to eat. The crunching sound gives us a tonne of information, meaning a lot of information about the food's freshness.

So, crunchy food sounds healthy, feels good and tells our body it's safe to eat. No wonder that when astronauts on the International Space Station were asked what they missed most, crunchy food topped their list. But apples and carrots are one thing, Beth. It's something else to crunch down on insects, isn't it?

Celebrity chef Dulce Midequa uses the crunchy texture of beetles, termites and locusts to convince people to try insect protein as a cheap alternative to meat. And if you think you could never eat insects, listen as Dulce explains how she changed her mind to Ruth Alexander, presenter of BBC World Service programme The Food Chain.

Ruth asked Dulce if she's an insect convert, a person who has changed their ideas or way of living. And Dulce replies, yes, she didn't before, but now she loves eating roast insects as snacks, small bits of food you eat between meals.

Well, speaking of apples, it's time you revealed the answer to your question. Yes, I asked you which was the most popular apple according to a survey of people in the UK. I said pink lady, didn't I? You did. And it was the correct answer. Well done. OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned, starting with two positive phrases. Nothing better in the world, which is used to emphasise how much someone enjoys something.

And one of life's true pleasures, which describes a particular experience or activity that someone finds enjoyable. A ton of something means a lot of something. If you describe food as mushy, you mean it's soft, the opposite of crunchy. A convert is a person who has changed their beliefs or way of living. And finally, a snack is a small bit of food you eat between meals, for example, crisps or a chocolate bar. And once again, our six minutes are up. But if you're ready for more, just head over to
our website bbclearningenglish.com for a quiz and worksheet for this programme. See you there soon. Bye. Bye.
